fields.headline: Sport news in brief
fields.bodyText: Ali Carter faces cancer fight The former World Championship runner-up Ali Carter, 34, has been diagnosed with lung cancer. Carter, who suffers from Crohn’s disease, last year recovered from testicular cancer to resume his career. The World Professional Billiards and Snooker Association chairman Jason Ferguson said: “Ali is the toughest competitor I know and, having spoken to him over the last few days, I can assure everyone he has the fight to get through the battle ahead.” Jimmy White, who was diagnosed with testicular cancer in 1995, wrote on Twitter: “Absolutely gutted for Ali, praying for you mate.” Carter had been due to play yesterday in Gloucester, in qualifying stages for the Wuxi Classic. He played almost a full season after being diagnosed with testicular cancer last summer, ending at the World Championship in Sheffield. A professional since 1996, Carter is ranked 13th in the world and has been as high as No2. PA David Weir sets world wheelchair mile record David Weir has set a world record for the wheelchair mile, but failed in his attempt to be the first man to go under the three-minute mark. The 34-year-old was taking part in the Bupa Westminster Mile in London, marking the 60th anniversary of Sir Roger Bannister’s sub-four-minute time over the distance. “I gave it my best shot,” said Weir after completing the course in 3min 7sec. Bannister greeted Weir after he was first to cross the finish line and the 85-year-old was optimistic that the six-time Paralympic champion could break the three-minute barrier next year. He said: “I hope so. He tells me he has managed to break three minutes in Richmond Park but I think that was a downhill course. He still has a little bit more to try out before he does it but I think he might manage it next year.” In the British One Mile Road Championships, Chris O’Hare won the men’s race in a time of 4min 5.03sec while Alison Leonard took the women’s title in 4:32.90.
